Hello and welcome!


I have created this website to display some of the projects that I have made during the course at Coursera by the Duke University
about the basics of HTML, CSS and Javascript. I am going to comment on the new technics I have learned throughout
the course and explain my actions on some of my choices.


The first HTML-element I worked with was the canvas.
I styled the two canvases with CSS and gave them a size, a color and an id.
The buttons below run functions which refer to the ids of the canvases and change their colors.

change the color



After that I have learned about colorvalues and how they are defined in a computer.
With the color picker you can choose every color a computer is able to display.
I even used it to set colorborders for the filters later on.

choose your favourite color




The next element is the slider. When the slider is pulled a yellow rectangle appears and will grow or shrink
depending on which direction you move the slider to.
At this stage, the most important thing I have learned is how to clear a canvas.
Every time you change the size of the rectangle the old one will be deleted and a new one is created.
Otherwise the rectangles would be drawn on top of each other and a difference
would only be visible if a bigger rectangle is created.


pull the slider





The first more challenging part of the course was to build the following filter function.
One can upload an image and choose between the different filters. However, the first row of filters handles every image equally.
But i was not satisfied with that because if one wanted to use a red filter on an image with a green background, the background would turn yellow.
To solve this problem I created a second row of filters. I tried out different methods to change the colorvalues the way I wanted them to be.
As a result I set borders for the colortones and depending on how i wanted the outcome to be a different function is called.



choose a filter






The last task was to create a filter which merges two images.
It scans the colorvalues from each pixel of the first image and if the greenvalue is bigger than the redvalue and the bluevalue
combined the program replaces it with a pixel from the second image. To make sure that this filter would work as expected
I had to adjust the two images so that the amount of pixels are identical.



use the greenscreen filter

start with the greenscreen image


for best results I recommend to use these images: greenscreen image, second image
